description.narrative: Accelerator Lab for Malaysia CO is a key initiative aimed at ensuring that UNDP is fit for purpose to deliver a new generation of solutions in line with the challenges the world faces.

condition.narrative: UNDP as the Implementing Partner will comply with the policies, procedures and practices of the United Nations Security Management System (UNSMS.)

description.narrative: 1. Number and diversity of new data sources used at CO level 2. Number of sustainable development solutions identified and documented 3. Variety of innovation methods used to test and iterate over different hypotheses 4. Working out loud: learning shared with a public audience outside of UNDP 5. Proportion of UNDP CO programming influenced by the Accelerator Lab's work and methodologies

comment.narrative: Baseline (year 2018) for all the indicators below, is zero. Data science, solutions mapping, experimentation/hypothesis testing, working out loud, and AccLab influence on CO programming are all new lines of work in the CO.

1. 9 different data sources, 10 new data sources 2. 50 new potential solutions 3. 10 innovation methods per Action Plan 4. 8 blogs, or other (substantial) media posts published per year. 5. At least 50% of our learning challenges have the public sector or other partner as counterpart. 6. At least one government entity or partner has adopted an accelerator lab method. 7. At least 50% of our learning challenges are providing actionable knowledge to ongoing CO projects. 8. The lab interacts at least once a week with another lab in the network. (48 interaction per year) 9. 50% of information shared across the network should be methodology, or sustainable development issue and opportunity related. 10. The Accelerator Lab Network’s work is featured at least 3 times per month in Country Office Social Media channels and tag UNDP Accelerator Labs accounts. The Lab team engages at least once a month across any social media conversation related to the work of the Accelerator Lab Network, from either personal or CO account. 11. Connect the Accelerator Lab’s publications to local development ecosystem through social media. Identify and engage with 10 new relevant local social media profiles of the broader Development Ecosystem.

1. 9 different data sources, 10 new data sources
- IMELC digitalization– citizen generated data, user journey, collective intelligence
- NTIS-IMM – qualitative interview, primary data and secondary data
- Sabah e-commerce – user journey, qualitative interview, observation
- Japanese Innovation Challenge Solar Dryer – Primary data, secondary data, stakeholder engagement, prototyping
- IsDB MSME Resilience– interviews, secondary data
- Reimagining urban space, ecosystems and communities (UBC, Riverine Work, Animonsta) – citizen generated data, qualitative interviews and focus groups, ethnographic data, community maps
2. 50 new potential solutions
- 25 solutions from SICA, 10 Solutions from NTIS-UNDP IMM, 10 solutions from UNCDF FIKRA Accelerator, 10 solutions from BNM MyFintech Week
3. 10 innovation methods per Action Plan
- Reimagining urban space, ecosystems and communities—behavioural insights, data visualisation, micro-narratives, positive deviance, systems thinking, sense-making, co-creation, gamification, prototyping
- Sabah e-commerce project and Japanese Innovation – Prototyping, Pilot, Proof of Concpet, co-creation, community assets (mapping)
- IsDB MSME Resilience – Solution mapping, pilots
- IMELC – gamification, behavioural insights
4. 8 blogs, or other (substantial) media posts published per year.
- UNDP-NTIS IMM https://www.my.undp.org/content/malaysia/en/home/blog/fireside-chat-on-impact-technology-for-sdg-progress.html
- Animonsta Nudge Experiment - https://www.my.undp.org/content/malaysia/en/home/blog/2021/animation-and-nudging-change--a-behavioural-insight-experiment-o.html
- A habitat for all - https://www.my.undp.org/content/malaysia/en/home/blog/2021/a-habitat-for-all.html
- The future is LIT: Youth leadership for human and planetary health- https://www.my.undp.org/content/malaysia/en/home/blog/2021/the-future-is-lit--youth-leadership-for-human-and-planetary-heal.html
- Lessons learnt from Micro-, Small and Medium Enterprises (MSMEs) Day 2021 – Supporting MSMEs for a more sustainable and resilient recovery in Malaysia- https://www.my.undp.org/content/malaysia/en/home/blog/2021/-lessons-learnt-from-micro---small-and-medium-enterprises--msmes.html
- Can I bee your friend? Getting to know our urban wildlife - https://www.my.undp.org/content/malaysia/en/home/blog/2021/can-i-bee-your-friend--getting-to-know-our-urban-wildlife.html
- Don’t deny the Dodo: Exploring urban biodiversity as a nature-based solution for ecosystem restoration - https://www.my.undp.org/content/malaysia/en/home/blog/2021/don_t-deny-the-dodo--exploring-urban-biodiversity-as-a-nature-ba.html
- E-commerce for Rural Development: A Response to COVID-19 Recovery- https://www.my.undp.org/content/malaysia/en/home/blog/2021/e-commerce-for-rural-development--a-response-to-covid-19-recover.html
- Democratizing futures through trial, error and exploration- https://www.my.undp.org/content/malaysia/en/home/blog/2021/democratizing-futures-through-trial--error-and-exploration.html
- When learning goes digital: Reflections on urban youth living in poverty in Malaysia -https://www.my.undp.org/content/malaysia/en/home/blog/2021/when-learning-goes-digital--reflections-on-urban-youth-living-in.html
- Explorers, assemble!- https://acceleratorlabs.undp.org/content/acceleratorlabs/en/home/blogs/explorers-global-summit-data-science.html
5. At least 50% of our learning challenges have the public sector or other partner as counterpart.
- MaGIC, TONIBUNG and Moyog Innovation House for Sabah e-commerce Project
- NTIS and several impact investors for NTIS- UNDP IMM Programme
- IRDA and Google Inc for IMELC Digitalisation
- MEDAC for Islamic Development Bank MSME Resilience Project
- Alliance for River Three , Universiti Malaya Water Warriors,for Reimagining urban space, ecosystems and communities
6. At least one government entity or partner has adopted an accelerator lab method.
- NTIS on Impact Measurement and Management
- IRDA on co-creation with stakeholders and digitalization through user journey
- FRIM adopted citizen science methodologies for its education and outreach work in the Northern
Peninsular states
- Alliance for River Three has adopted Google Earth tools for public engagement
7. At least 50% of our learning challenges are providing actionable knowledge to ongoing CO projects.
- Sabah e-commerce on engagement with MOSTI, MEDAC, OA MGF and
MOF Sustainable Tourism Project, TBI Digitalisation Concept
- IMELC digitalisation on IRDA’s green technology and low carbon city future project
- NTIS-UNDP IMM project on IMM Data Framework with Cradle and SICA 2.0/Shift! partnership
scaling for 2022 with MRANTI

8. The lab interacts at least once a week with another lab in the network. (48 interaction per year)
- the Lab interacts once a week with other labs
9. 50% of information shared across the network should be methodology, or sustainable development issue and opportunity related.
- Everything (100%) of information shared across the network is related to innovation methodologies we have tested in the AccLab; social, economic and/or environmental issues with a sustainable development framework; or opportunities for exploration or partnership.
10. The Accelerator Lab Network’s work is featured at least 3 times per month in Country Office Social Media channels and tag UNDP Accelerator Labs accounts. The Lab team engages at least once a month across any social media conversation related to the work of the Accelerator Lab Network, from either personal or CO account.
data deficient — cannot determine.
11. Connect the Accelerator Lab’s publications to local development ecosystem through social media. Identify and engage with 10 new relevant local social media profiles of the broader Development Ecosystem.
data deficient — cannot determine.

1. N/A (new indicator introduced in 2020) 2. 1 local solution addressing a key local challenge identified using new methods 3. 1 experiment undertaken by the AccLab 4. 1 blog 5. 10% of CO programming influenced by AccLab

1. N/A 2. 0. 1 local solution in Sabah addressing livelihood challenges in rural communities documented during conventional field visits methods. 3. 0. This setback was partly due to late onboarding of the Head of Experimentation (January 2020). Once the AccLab was complete, the first experiment was conducted in February 2020. Initial exploration and scoping for the first experiment was performed in December 2019. 4. 1 blog published in December 2019. 5. 0%. The AccLab was onboarded late (and incomplete) in October 2019. The AccLab Bootcamp coincided with the COs Theory of Change retreat; the AccLab was thus unable to offer any input here.
That said, the AccLab worked hard to establish itself in and beyond the CO in the last 2.5 months of 2019. 1. Conducted two brown bags post-Bootcamp to advertise and share AccLab methodologies with the CO. 2. Led revision/re-design the COs MYPR reporting instruments. 3. Provided field support (sensemaking and exploration) on missions to the states of Sabah and Sarawak, to explore new programme opportunities. 4. Made over 100 external potential partnership connections, including private sector, NGOs and civil society organisations and individuals. 5. Conducted AccLab methodology workshops (sensemaking, solutions mapping and basic foresight) to internal and external stakeholders: e.g., UNDP Orang Asli Micro Grant Facility (OA-MGF), and Ministry of Education/Student Volunteers Foundation Volunteer Leadership Development Programme (YSS-VLDP).
1. 6 different data sources, 5 new data sources 2. 35 new potential solutions 3. 5 per portfolio 4. 6 blogs, videos or other (substantial) media posts 5. 15% of CO programming influenced by AccLab

1. The Malaysia AccLab made use of 19 data sources, 18 of which were new, across 8 data types.
i. Taman Ampang Jajar observations-Ethnographic ii. WFH survey-Survey iii.ReformARTsi survey-Survey iv. PSAR survey-Survey v. UNCDF gig worker survey-Survey vi. Animonsta pre-/post-campaign-Survey vii. U-report solution mapping-Citizen data/public campaign viii. Animonsta pledge event-Citizen data/public campaign ix. WFH scanning-Facebook-Social media x. WFH scanning-Instagram-Social media xi. PSAR interviews-Interviews/FGD xii. Taylor’s interviews-Interviews/FGD xiii. YSS focus group discussions-Interviews/FGD xiv. DJKL interviews/FGDs-Interviews/FGD xv. MHC interviews/FGDs-Interviews/FGD xvi. WAO helpline-Other xvii. Kisah Futures Competition-Crowdsourced text data xviii. DOSM-Structured statistical data xix. Sabah e-commerce-Interviews/FGD/ Citizen data
2. The Malaysia AccLab identified over 70 new local solutions, 2 of which were nominated for awards by the HoneyBee Network
3. The Malaysia AccLab had 2 portfolios in 2020 (COVID-19 response and Environment). In the first portfolio, we had 14 different innovation methods (horizon scanning; micro-narratives; social media analysis; co-creation, pilots, sensemaking; citizen science; participatory design; solutions mapping; crowdsourcing; prototyping; collective intelligence; data ethnography; data visualization) over 4 frontier challenges (Work From Home; Sabah E-Commerce; Kisah and Solutions Mapping; and PRIHATIN assessment). In the second portfolio, we had 5 different innovation methods (behavioral insights, social media analysis, proof of concept, randomized controlled trial, citizen science) under 1 frontier challenge (Animonsta/IMELC)
4. The Malaysia AccLab published 12 blogs and 3 videos (U-Report Solutions Mapping, Kisah Arts Survey, and the Animonsta video)
5. The Malaysia AccLab and CO Management have not yet defined what it means for a CO programme to be influenced by the AccLab. We have been heavily involved in CO programming, however. Highlights include: leading or substantially contributing to development of 3 research project concept notes; providing substantial support for the development of the Area Based Programming concept and implementation; providing support for online collaboration tools in many ongoing projects; reviewing and giving input into COVID-19 social economic impact reports; and contributing in many formal and informal discussions in project conceptualisation.

1. 7 different data sources, 5 new data sources
2. 25 new potential solutions
3. 8 innovation methods per Action Plan
4. 10 blogs, or other (substantial) media posts published per year.
5. At least 50% of our learning challenges have the public sector or other partner as counterpart.
6. At least one government entity or partner has adopted an accelerator lab method.
7. At least 50% of our learning challenges are providing actionable knowledge to ongoing CO projects.
8. The lab interacts at least once a week with another lab in the network. (48 interaction per year)

development issue and opportunity related.

11. Connect the Accelerator Lab’s publications to local development ecosystem through social media. Identify and engage with 10 new relevant local social media profiles of the broader Development Ecosystem.
